Award.AwardTitle: Incorporation Of Ethnic Minorities In Colonial Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Adela Amaral, of the University of California, Berkeley, along with an international team of American graduate students and Mexican researchers, will conduct research in the state of Oaxaca to investigate 1) colonial black runaway slavery, or marronage 2) the process through which new ethnicities are created in a colonial context, and 3) the disparity between how places were constructed in colonial texts and how they were experienced by colonized people. These questions will be investigated in Amapa, a town founded by black slaves escaping plantation slavery during Mexico's late colonial in 1769. In the Americas, including the United States, maroon communities have been characterized as existing in obscured and marginal places such as swamps or mountains. This research, however, focuses on a town that was not consigned to geographic backwoods, but that was legally founded by black runaway slaves, or maroons, with the approval of colonial officials. Despite their legal and spatial relocation, however, the Amapa settlers were nonetheless perceived as maroons by others and depicted in a hostile light. The process of incorporating the maroonsinto colonial society rested on the assumption that they were capable of becoming docile colonial subjects. Towns, in effect, were the cornerstones of colonial civility. Paradoxically, the Amapa maroons continued to be portrayed as savages" unworthy, and perhaps incapable, of "civilization". What has not been examined is how the process of colonial incorporation was realized in the everyday experiences of Amapa residents. This research is of broader relevance because it provides a context and comparative case for understanding problems of perception of minorities and their incorporation into a multi-ethinc societies such as that which exist in the United States today. Similar processes are also occurring currently in many other regions of the world.

This issue will be explored through a combination of archaeological investigations, artifact analysis, and archaeometric work. Excavated materials from Amapa will be compared to information recorded in colonial documents about the maroons' social and material practices both prior to and after their resettlement. Specifically, this project will focus on four categories of evidence: a) settlement space, b) food acquisition, preparation, and consumption, c) artifact use, and d) circulations of regional ceramics through archaeometric analysis. The latter will examine the chemical content of selected materials to track the provenance and movement of pottery. In addition to contributing original, scientific data to maroon studies and Mexican colonial history, the proposed project will involve the present-day Amapa community in all steps of the research design, fieldwork, and interpretation. Training American graduate students and local residents in archaeological thinking and methodology is also a main objective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Incorporation of Ethnic Minorities in Colonial Contexts, NSF Award Number 1632368, was an archaeological research project located in Amapa, a town in the Mexican state of Oaxaca. Here, formerly enslaved African-descendant workers who fled Spanish colonial sugar plantations, called "maroons" by scholars, founded Amapa as a free town in 1769. From the point of view of the colonial officials who authorized the town’s foundation, Amapa was an experiment in transforming people. The foundation of Amapa was an attempt to remake the residents into colonial subjects who would lead sedentary, Christian, agriculturalist lives, and protect the colony from other people fleeing slavery. These colonial officials followed a theory of governance in which material order promoted social order. A map of the town from 1770 in fact illustrates a neatly organized settlement, exemplifying the expected patterns of life. Scholars who have conducted historical research on Amapa assumed the people conformed to the expectations of the colonial order.

The archaeological research undertaken in this project examined the material evidence of what people actually did in the town of Amapa, based on traces of their activities. By comparing Amapa’s archaeological materials with historical documents, this investigation considered if the residents indeed became the ideal colonial subjects they were expected to become. Finding significant evidence that people did not follow expected patterns of activity, the project sought to understand the actual kind of collective life that the formerly enslaved individuals constructed for themselves.

Intellectual merit: Excavations, approved by the Mexican National Council of Archaeology, were conducted across two field seasons. The following three research questions guided this work: 1) Did the 1770 plan map accurately reflect how the town was built? 2) How did settlers use the space in the town? 3) Does excavated material speak to a continued way of life rooted in previous practices, as described in colonial documents? To answer these questions, three categories of evidence were used: a) patterns in settlement space; b) types of artifacts discarded; and c) food remains.

First results suggest that the Amapa settlers did not use their town as colonial officials intended. Pre-resettlement, these people were reported as having a highly mobile existence, consuming specific types of food that included products of wide-ranging hunting and plant harvesting. Areas that show architectural development on the 1770 map were excavated in the first field season, but produced little evidence of habitation. Few artifacts were recovered, and deposits were shallow. In the second field season, evidence was produced of more intensive use of the area adjacent to the town church. Instead of using the regimented town as their primary place for activities, the formerly enslaved residents appear to have maintained an extensive use of space beyond the town, while using parts of the town for specific community-related purposes.

This project is providing materially based interpretations about race and racialization for Mexico’s colonial history that can be compared across colonial contexts. This project focuses on a subset of colonial lives and experiences that are poorly documented– runaway slaves of African descent. It provides material data on how racial categories influence everyday activities that are fundamentally spatial and material. Places and material cultures are defined socially, often in opposing and racial terms – Spanish, or "white" orderly towns contrasting with the mountains inhabited by African descendants fleeing enslavement, for instance – but these neat racialized divisions are often challenged in practice. The residents of Amapa, formerly enslaved people of African descent with a fugitive history, unsettled colonial categories when they settled a colonial town– one of the material pinnacles of white civility. Yet they did not live in that town as the colonial authorities expected.

Two academic research articles have resulted from this work so far. Final laboratory analysis which is expected to lead to additional publications is on hold because of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Broader Impacts: this project contributed to the training of future participants in science. American undergraduate and graduate students participated in both field seasons and were trained in various aspects of archaeology including mapping, excavations, and artifact identification. The project also increased public appreciation for science. Local residents were introduced to archaeological methods through their employment in the project, and school activities were organized for Amapa students yearly.
